topic.title: kB limit on Zer0Talk
topic.body:
So I've noticed the kB limit on Zer0Talk is 50kB, is there any way to increase this? Or do I have to create a new identity when I hit this limit?

This limit is there to keep the total size of the zite down, but we could allow people to post unlimited messages by splitting them in multiple files and only sharing the most recent 50kB-max file. Optionally download everything for users you "follow". Or something along those lines.

topic.title: Some zite development questions
topic.body:
* Is it possible to split content.json up into multiple parts? I have tons of optional files, I'm talking millions of files, and I don't really want to have to sign those in one go whenever a couple of them are changed or new ones added.
* Is there a way to rename a file for download? html normally has <a href="original" download="renamed">, but this doesn't work in ZeroNet.

topic.title: Anyone from ZeroNet going to FOSDEM 2019?
topic.body:
I'll be going there for both GodotCON and FOSDEM. There'll be a "decentralized internet and privacy" that I'm particularly interested in, and I imagine others here might be as well.
https://fosdem.org/2019/

topic.title: ZeroNet DBSchema feature request: insert list size into db
topic.body:
given a json:
```
{
  "vehicles":[
    "car",
    "bicycle",
    "bus",
    "boat",
    "train"
  ]
}
```
I would like to insert into the db table `| vehicles | 5 |` instead of inserting all items and then counting them.

@nofish

topic.title: Big files not loading?
topic.body: I've got a 22MB file in my content.json but when I load it on another pc every file except that single one is downloaded fine! Am I doing something wrong?

topic.title: Working on a File Deduplication Plugin for ZeroNet
topic.body:
Hey peeps here on ZN!

I really like the idea of file deduplication for zeronet, making it a bit more like IPFS (but better!) So I've been studying the ZN code and I think it should be possible to make a plugin to do so, but I could definitely use some help from others here who've been here longer.

Why?
* This will make moving from old zites to new forks/alternatives easier! Now we have KopyKate, Youtube, KxoVid and several other videohosting zites and that's great! But what's not is that if you want to make your video available on all these zites, you need to have that many copies on your drive (or you could ln them, but let's be honest we aren't going to diligently do that because we're lazy like that).
* This could even make it possible to have a zite where you can upload a video to all networks AT THE SAME TIME. But that's not going to happen any time soon...
* Keep files alive/available for longer
* Save space, duhh!

What am I proposing?
* File deduplication serves no purpose for small files, so for starters let's limit it to bigfiles.
* An option to include smaller files of certain filetypes (e.g. only images, music and video) for those who want. It would be pointless to store json files because those are highly unlikely to have doubles on ZN.
* Optional folders to scan (read-only), hashes found there will not be downloaded and can be seeded directly from their location.
* If a double is edited locally, write it to the other location (we don't want to edit both!)
* A big button to look for duplicates and remove one of them.

What is working so far?
* After (manually) deleting duplicated files, they are still locally accessible as long as there is one copy in location (or other zite).

Looking for suggestions on:
* How do we handle owned zites? We need to stop non-optional files from getting removed from content.json when signing (because they're not really there) do we do db lookups when signing as well, or just exclude it for ease?
* When deleting doubles, which one? The one that isn't in an owned zite I propose. Any other things to keep in mind when deciding?

Looking for documentation(/a friendly explanation by someone more knowledgeable) on:
* How the ZeroNet server works, how and where is it configured.
* How does the whole torrenting thing work? Is it possible to look for peers based on the SHA512 without first going to the zite pool?

**I'd love to hear what people think about this!** Is it pointless? Harder than I think? Why don't we just use IPFS? etc. Let me know.

topic.title: The protests are a puppet show, but we're not the audience
topic.body:
The point isn't to challenge the system, as the system could just crush it if they thought there was any danger. The point of protesting, in the modern sense, is to *buttress the establishment* by building up a mythological backstory around any change the system wants to make so that future generations have a context for those changes that is difficult to deconstruct, rather than a rational one which may be easy to deconstruct if the reasoning is flawed. Future generations will be told stories about how everything was bad in the 20's, until the brave protesters forced the state's hand, and that is how these new laws were passed, and *you*, for wanting freedom and challenging these laws, *must want to send us back to a time of bad*.

People will then look at the media records from today and will see that yes, there *was* in fact all of these problems, and yes, there *was* in fact all of these protests, and yes, there *were* in fact changes following them.

They will not have the experience to question the narrative of today's press, and they will not be able to study the context. The dissenting opinions standing up against the media now will by then have 404'd from the internet, unlisted by Google, removed from Facebook, Twitter and other social media that stood the test of time. The internet archives have gone, sued by the press over copyright infringement, and pressured by activist organizations and social media mobs for spreading misinformation and giving a platform to bigotry. There will be traces left, here and there, blog posts and amateur's archives run over anonymous networks, but few will stumble upon them as the tech giants route all traffic to their verified, trustworthy partners.
 
And so they will get sucked into the fairy tale.

Repealing unpopular laws will be impossible, just like how the laws surrounding Holocaust denial are untouchable, even though they fly in the face of the freedom of expression the West proclaims to support.

Of course there will be those that try. They will privately send compilations of distorted jpeg's recompressed as webp's to those they trust, accompanied by pdf copies of defunct websites full of broken links. All of this supporting their claim that today wasn't as bad as the historians say, that the evil caricatures portrayed in the media were cherry-picked from the fringes of society, disliked by all. And their friends will not respond, except for those who will call them conspiracy theorists and beg them to stop.

And then there will be those brave few who will stand up for their opinions publicly, and their posts will be marked as unreliable by the bots, if not outright removed. The supporting video evidence they upload, the Federal Bureau of Manipulation will claim, has been doctored and the file's hashes have been added to a database of disinformative multimedia files so that future uploads can be prevented. For their bravery they will be rewarded the prospect of unemployment and friends who shun them publicly.

*Truth must be protected valiantly*, that is the mantra of the bureau, *lest Democracy die in darkness*.

That is what protests are about.

**It's about protecting the bullshit of tomorrow by building its mythological foundation today.**

**+++ NEVER LET GEORGE ORWELL BE FORGOTTEN +++**
Internet Archive Censorship: https://reclaimthenet.org/internet-archives-censorship/
EU proposes Upload Filters: https://juliareda.eu/2018/11/eu-council-upload-filters/
Google results only go up to 10 years ago: http://stop.zona-m.net/2018/01/indeed-it-seems-that-google-is-forgetting-the-old-web/
**+++ NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR WAS NOT A MANUAL +++**

topic.title: Free Speech in the COVID-era is Doomed, Long Live Censorship-Resistance
topic.body:
The People are not allowed to assemble to practice their First Amendment rights, so we can only communicate using the internet, and now Silicon Valley is going into full crackdown mode on top of that.

If you are here on ZeroNet, you probably already realized that Free Speech is dying, and you want to hold on as long as you can. Until today I didn't realize just how important networks like ZeroNet will be, nay, already are.  How often haven't I heard people argue that "these companies can do what they want, because they're not the public space, if you want free speech, go to a public park or the town square". But the government won't allow us to assemble and air our grievances to one another. The only outlet many of us have is through the internet, and for those who are not tech-savvy enough to know about or discover ZeroNet, nor any of the clearnet alternatives like Minds, Parler, Gab, etc. that means Free Speech is effectively already dead.

Facebook and Twitter will quite literally scan your private messages for banned links and *not* send them to your friends. Maybe you're sending your friends e-mails, but oh wait, you signed up with Gmail or Hotmail and considering the positions of their parent companies how long will it take until they start blocking your e-mails because you were critical of a vaccine, or an election?

> “That rifle on the wall of the labourer's cottage or working class flat is the symbol of democracy. It is our job to see that it stays there.”
> ― George Orwell

> [0033300](#comment_7_1JwAJqcH78mtHGwLHyQZ5jvi5si8kJDeq9): there is no future. [...]

pretty much, and it's biologically and politically impossible to stop. Science was a mistake that religious dogmatism protected us from. It's the real pandora's box and we should never have touched it.

> [timelinehyperbot](#comment_7_12JYCt1Mj1Fa7GA9N67HAxP6NiBHVWK9GS): I'm not touchy, but what is with your pandora's box speech...  The Sky is falling, the Sky is falling!!! ... Ok I get it but what are you going to do to make a better World!?
Then what is with the "oh no someone assumed my gender on the internet!", that sounds pretty touchy to me.

It's too late, matey. Could pull a unabomber, but that's not going to make the world a better place, now is it? Better to just march on to our demise with open eyes. I myself live a low-impact life: local produce, no traveling, as little plastics as possible, no modern medicine unless absolutely necessary, etc. but there's no way enough people in the world will return to a more traditional and modest way of life. Instead the third world will adopt the degenerate customs of the West and consolidate the destruction of our planet. And that's just on the environmentalist side of things, politically things are fucked too, but they're tied together because governments will abuse the destruction of earth to turn citizens globally more and more into slaves. They won't be able to solve the problems, because that's not in the interest of their corporate sponsors, but they'll damn well use those problems to scare us into submission. Same way with immigration: is it going to destabilize the world? Yes. But corporations like the lowered wages. What people need to realize is that all political parties are cucks: they're all just cucks to different wealthy interests.

I'm not trying to blackpill people. Don't give up. Fight with what you've got. But realize that you've probably been fighting someone else's war, and that in the meantime your own battles are being lost.

1541360464_154aXdhb7aoQmT62rxDp6HKte3V1j.body:
I really like the idea in principle, however in practice it's old software that has had a long time to catch on, and it just hasn't. It's slow, it isn't user-friendly (eg. you have to manually install plugins to get the best out of it), I've given it a try, but unless they give it a makeover I don't think it has any chances of ever gaining popularity outside of a fringe group of nerds.
Beaker/dat is probably one of the projects doing the best publicity-wise, reaching even the ears of people who know little about tech -- I personally hope they don't win out, although I've got to hand them something: you only host websites you "bookmark" and you can browse earlier versions of those websites. They also use dat:// urls (which looks better than ZNs localhost:port/url, but it requires their special browser while we can use any browser we want. It's very similar to ZN apart from that.

> [jaggedelectrons](#comment_5_16B6aFfFUjn2hchrBDuvSFgUymhbQMGJrS): If I seed a few videos on KopyKate [...]

There you have it, you chose to download and seed those. You didn't download them and keep them by default to seed until you manually removed them. You expressly chose to download and seed them.
I would prefer the same be true for zites. Sometimes I click a link out of curiosity and I will never ever visit that zite again, and I may not consider it worth sharing. I would feel more comfortable if ZeroNet just forgot about that zite when I leave rather than me having to remember to delete it.

Another thing I have been wondering about, and that I am slightly worried about is the following:
If I happen upon a zite hosting illegal content, I can delete that zite and move on -- no problem there. If I happen upon a zite that just looks dull (e.g. "This EPIC site is in development, keep the url and come back in a month"), but secretly has non-optional files with illegal content *I won't know about it, but I will still be hosting it!* This could potentially be abused to have people unwittingly host illegal files <10MB, which isn't much *but still enough to cause serious trouble.*
This seems to me to be a serious flaw in the system. I can live with it *existing* on the network -- that's inevitable. I can live with parts of it existing in encrypted storage in my freenet drive -- that's necessary for the system to operate. But *I don't want to have to explain to police why it's on my harddrive.*

I won't quit using ZN over this, but it is an issue that should be discussed.

1541554639_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
I believe under the current system, yes.

ZeroNet should introduce an IPFS-like cross-site filesystem where it doesn't even matter on what site the file is hosted. Or ZeroNet+IPFS packed together.

1541600740_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3X.body:
Morals are gay. Nature will always prevail, and nature does not follow any moral code, only what works and what doesn't. Western morals don't work and will collapse. The Islamic morals are stronger -- not perfect, but they don't have to be.

I have preferred morals, ones I would prefer to live amongst -- but I don't believe those morals are true, or the best, or anything of the sort.

> [sheendocks] One of the things I dislike about ZeroNet is that with the added anonymity it gives people a cover to be shameless and post some very base material (I'm looking at those of you uploading child abuse).

I still find it a hard pill to swallow, but it's the price to pay for free speech, and by extension truth, and I'm willing to pay that price. Take liveleaks, it's a very important sort of service for exposing horrible violence and accidents that would be wiped from almost any other site -- and some of which would be illegal to post online in certain countries! A lot of it is disgusting and I can't stomach to watch it, but I'm glad it is out there to document e.g. the horrors of ISIL, or the US army killing innocent people.

I don't really think you can compare that to child abuse, but once you rationally accept the importance of anonymity and a person's ability to post content that goes against societies sensibilities -- and possibly laws -- there's just no way around it: *anonymity as an option is necessary in the pursuit of truth*. The best you can do is shield yourself from content you object to (blacklists), and link the material to the authorities if it is illegal in nature so that they may identify the perpetrators.

*Refusing to adopt anonymity-capable systems like ZN will do absolutely nothing to hurt abusers.* However without wider adoption of such technologies the consequences for the people will be severe, with our more and more authoritarian governments. The idea that governments will arrest you for saying mean words on the internet would've been crazy 10 years ago -- now that's normal! Europe has been looking at China's GFW drooling -- and I'm not pointing fingers at any one side: left, center and right all desire the power to censor dissidents (generally more among the left though).

1543748747_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
> [timelinehyperbot](#comment_77_12JYCt1Mj1Fa7GA9N67HAxP6NiBHVWK9GS): [...]

Read up on your cryptography. You're clearly misunderstanding what leftside is saying here.

1) recipient broadcasts public key to everyone

2) On sender's side: `cleartext + recipient public key => cyphertext`

3) On receiver's side: `cyphertext + recipient private key => cleartext`

> [timelinehyperbot](#comment_74_12JYCt1Mj1Fa7GA9N67HAxP6NiBHVWK9GS): "Let's make a public-key-encrypted text that only the paired private key owner can read." ... Your comment. [...]

... The private key owner has to give you a paired public key. leftside made that clear...

This. The growing climate of censorship will lead to increased interest in censorship-resistant technologies, but don't let that lead you to inaction! There's still much to be done! As clobersontheman said: explain the importance of such technology and how it works to friends and family, and help foster a welcoming community on ZeroNet for newcomers. Original content, either mirrored (by author or endorsed by author) or even exclusive content, would be a great boon. One major selling point to OCs is that there's little competition on the network and their name will be immortalized in the history of ZeroNet. (If ZeroNet fails to become "the" censorship-resistant network of the future that might not mean much, ... but there's got to be creators willing to take the risk!

the problem is that if I download a file outside of zeronet that's also shared within zeronet, I can't just "add it to zeronet" and help sharing it, I would be adding a distinct copy of that file. ZeroNet should have an alternate purely hash-based way of pooling files that does not depend on the file-path. Hell -- integrate it with IPFS even! We don't have a lot of people here on ZeroNet and that makes seeders scarce, most certainly for older files.

1553596906_1Lh89nAb4YeizEER15JUcpscy37mZ.body:
This will not be doing more good than harm, that much is for certain. One thing the CD will do is make the GAFAM monopolies even stronger in their position. How are alternative tech sites like Minds, Mastodont, Gab, Bitchute, Peertube etc. going to deal with this? Chances are some of them will be forced to outright block european IPs once the directive goes into effect.
What we need to figure out is which MEPs voted for and never vote for them again or for parties that supported this directive like the scummy CDU.
Sadly most people won't notice what freedoms were lost today because they don't wander off the GAFAM plantation anyway.

How will ZeroNet do with this new directive? Not at all would be my guess. We need to be more worried about the Terrorist Content Regulation, that's more likely to target censorship resistent platforms.

> [4567l](#comment_4_1Lh89nAb4YeizEER15JUcpscy37mZwDUer): "The Copyright Directive protects freedom of expression, a core value of the European Union. It sets strong safeguards for users, making clear that everywhere in Europe the use of existing works for purposes of quotation, criticism, review, caricature as well as parody are explicitly allowed. This means that memes and similar parody creations can be used freely. The interests of the users are also preserved through effective mechanisms to swiftly contest any unjustified removal of their content by the platforms." [...]

Yes, yes, bureaucratic bullshit. There is no way for robots to understand fair use, but you need to use robots to realistically remove copyright infringement before it gets posted to comply, therefore the directive is self-contradictory. It don't matter how much bullshittery you tack on at the end saying "oh, but this won't hurt free speech". It will.

1553607490_1NYxK9cC899pvxFuCt6eE53APoueD.body:
[Article 13 Cometh (#SaveYourInternet)](https://www.bitchute.com/video/rmO7BdPcmlU/)
Either Swedish MEP are covering their arses because they know they fucked up, or we actually defeated Art 11 & 13, but -- the EU being a bureaucratic nightmare -- the vote to keep these articles was won because a last-minute change in the voting order had MEPs press the wrong button... either way this really reflects on how poorly the EU functions.

I also particularly like the part where Axel Voss claims "We're not trying to kill Youtube" two weeks after saying "Youtube shouldn't exist". Not that I like Youtube, it honestly shouldn't exist! But we should not kill it with regulation, and instead starve it of our valuable time and data. Let's move to better platforms.

1552807915_1CBZY3cuYKeHZXEeHVxRFLmsCr3Um.body:
> [malladis](#comment_1_18bPiPS2hgoc8pbS8Ku8aoWQ748jfC6vkV): Right, so basically it's impossible to run a site like Reddit/Facebook/Twitter etc. [...]

Not really, you just have to be innovative and split up the data somehow. You could look at RetroShare for inspiration (they have time, trust and "hub" constraints for what you download locally). Each subreddit could be a merger (e.g. Millchan Engine as compared to Millchan Classic), you could work with optional files to decrease size (users have optional data.json per subreddit) or you could develop a new python plugin to handle it some other (even better) way if you can think of one. If it's good enough it can then be bundled with ZeroNet by default.

In the end ZeroNet is and will always be a work-in-progress where people come up with clever solutions as problems arise. Seeing as we're a relatively small community we haven't had many problems with scaleability and solving it has been low-priority (ZeroLSTN has had a scaleability problem though but that has more to do with songs/seeders ratio, this could be solved by dropping songs without seeders from the db but the dev is currently busy doing other things).

1610318482_16aoHyKbwpvBmgCtNqX1tW9N5bvXG.body:
Beaker/dat has less content than ZeroNet and several downsides:
- No support for Tor/I2P yet (But it's very simple to use ZeroNet with Tor, not with I2P yet though)
- Need to keep browser open to seed sites (ZeroNet can run in the background)

But some things I do like about Beaker are:
- Versioned sites
- Custom browser (but this can also be a downside though, it means they have to maintain their browser, which is likely to be time intensive, and it means users are locked into a specific browser)

BTW: If you really want to stay anonymous with ZeroNet you'll have to use ZN+Tor and use TBB (Tor Browser Bundle) with 127.0.0.1 as whitelisted address. Even then you could accidentally reveal who you are by giving personal information. Unfortunately some sites (e.g. ZeroMe) don't play nice with TBB.

1610253332_1yhTF4WKRZsCBdVeh8fwPj14zAiEd.body:
It's hard to pinpoint down what ZeroNet is competing with exactly because it is so different from anything else. I recommend reading some of the blog posts on http://127.0.0.1:43110/13T79X7tG8Fi3EZCev3xU1wYTtFHHnqWGQ/?Post:5 that were written after the 8chan influx.

The projects ZeroNet is the most similar to are FreeNet, Beaker/dat and SafeNet/MaidSafe (*decentralized hosting*), then one degree further away would be networks like Solid, Fediverse, Matrix, Mastodon (*federalized hosting*).
People often lump ZeroNet with Tor and I2P,  but that's just wrong. Tor and I2P (as well as e.g. LokiNet) are *anonymous and decentralized name resolution*, not hosting. FreeNet does both.

ZeroNet does more than just decentralized hosting because it also offers sites an API to interact with the data, which is what allows dynamic sites without using the blockchain (which is a bad idea). With ZeroNet you can use downloaded sites offline, and even share them on a LAN network. You can also share sites by USB drive if the internet is completely shut down, this makes it very resistant to censorship.

A very important point to make is that while ZeroNet is censorship-resistant, sites on ZeroNet don't have to be censorship resistant. IF you want to make a site and not allow something on that site, you can do so.
